title: Crochet
text:
Here are some of my favorite crochet pieces, along with the tutorials I used to make them!






Spider web topTutorialNote: The video tutorial includes sleeves, but if you want to recreate the top like how I made it, just skip that part!







Star messenger bagTutorialNote: The tutorial is for a smaller bag, but just add more chains/rows to increase the size. Lining the bag with sturdy fabric also prevents the bag from stretching!







Distressed topTutorial







Flower lace topTutorial

title: Portfolio
text:
Here are some writing pieces I did during my undergrad that I especially enjoyed working on. Hope you enjoy reading, and feel free to email me if you have any questions!

ENV S 149 Food, Agriculture, and the Environment:
“Filipino Cuisine with a side of…Colonialism?”- Blog post
This blog post explores the history of Spanish colonialism in the Philippines and how this has impacted Filipino food and agriculture, along with the subsequent Westernization of Filipino cuisine and how this connects to increased health risks prevalent in Filipino communities in the US.

ENV S 40 Critical Thinking and Evidence-Based Reasoning for the Environment:
“The Origins of Fast Fashion” - Zine
This zine is an investigation of our relationship with the environment and clothing and works to answer the question, “How has our relationship with the environment and clothing contributed to the rise of fast fashion.” It explores topics such as colonialism, capitalism, and consumerism and how this has impacted the environment and the fast fashion industry.

ENV S 101 Ecosystem Services and Biodiversity:
“The Kidneys of the Earth and the Hearts of California Native Americans” - Essay
This paper describes riparian wetlands and their ecological benefits, like erosion control and nitrogen removal, along with the cultural ecosystem services they provide, like the cultural and spiritual identity of California Native Americans. It also covers the effects of European colonization on riparian wetlands in CA and the importance of traditional ecological knowledge (TEK) and traditional resource management (TRM).

text:

title: Flower lace top
text:
Description
This lace top is more difficult compared to the other ones I’ve shown but once you get the hang of the pattern, it gets easier. I like paring this top with jeans or underneath overalls!


Materials
4.25mm crochet hook (I accidentally used a smaller hook)
DK yarn
Stitch markers (safety pins, paper clips, or bobby pins work great)
Darning needle
Scissors
Measuring tape



Tutorial
Here’s the youtube tutorial I followed to make this top!











Tips
It took me a long time to get the hang of this pattern, so if you’re having a hard time making this top too, don’t feel discouraged! I also found it difficult to see which part of the pattern I was making while crocheting each row. So, I recommend making a practice swatch to help you get used to identifying which part of the flower you’re crocheting.

title: Spider web top
text:
Description
This top is great for beginners and builds up super quickly too, making this a great last-minute Halloween outfit!


Materials
4.25mm crochet hook (I used a slightly larger hook for looser stitches)
Superfine-fine yarn (any thin yarn works)
Stitch markers (safety pins, paper clips, or bobby pins work great)
Darning needle
Scissors
Measuring tape
Patience


Tutorial
Here’s the youtube tutorial I followed to make this top!











Tips
I highly recommend using stitch markers to keep track of your rows because it can get a bit tricky as you go. Also, the video tutorial includes sleeves, but if you want to recreate the top like how I made it, just skip that part!

title: Distressed top
text:
Description
This top is a perfect project if you’re looking for something to make that will crochet the stress away. Although it might look intricate, this top only requires double crochets, and the distressed part is just a chain stretched out super long!


Materials
5mm crochet hook (I used a slightly larger hook for looser stitches)
DK yarn
Stitch markers (safety pins, paper clips, or bobby pins work great)
Darning needle
Scissors
Measuring tape



Tutorial
Here’s the youtube tutorial I followed to make this top!











Tips
Try to keep your tension looser than normal for a more distressed look, or try experimenting with different tensions and colors to add some interest! Also, you will get caught in things while wearing this top out but just embrace it (it also adds to the distressed look)

title: Star messenger bag
text:
Description
This bag is another great project for beginners because it’s made using one stitch (double crochet). I ended up making my bag around 9x12 inches, which fits my iPad, 24oz water bottle, headphones, keys, wallet, phone, and more. I also sewed a felt star onto my bag, but feel free to add any design you’d like!


Materials
5mm crochet hook
DK or worsted yarn
Stitch markers (safety pins, paper clips, or bobby pins work great)
Darning needle
Scissors
Measuring tape



Tutorial
Here’s the youtube tutorial that inspired this bag!











Tips
The above tutorial is for a smaller bag, but just add more chains and rows to increase the size. Lining the bag with sturdy fabric also prevents the bag from stretching! I also added a magnetic button for easy open/closure and an inside pocket for fast access to smaller items, along with a removable plastic bottom for extra support. If you decide to line your bag, I recommend using clear sewing thread so you don’t see your stitches.

title: Katelyn Vidal
text:
About me
Hi! I’m Katelyn Vidal, and I’m a third-year Environmental Studies major with a strong passion for ecological restoration. Some of my involvements at UCSB include being on the art committee for the Isla Vista Trading Post and volunteering with the Edible Campus Program. My hobbies include drawing, painting, gardening, crocheting, bird watching, and showing people pictures of my dogs.


Education
B.A. in Environmental Studies (2021 - Present)
University of California, Santa Barbara
